values.description:
See issue #44.

‌

* The 2D camera topic is now `/<ROBOT_NAME>/camera_front/image_raw` .
* The IMU topic is now `/<ROBOT_NAME>/imu/data` for all sensors.
* Rviz config files updated accordingly.

I haven’t modified the odometry for X3 and X4 until we clarify whether can be used or not.

‌

**Reminder: Update the API doc with the new camera topic.**
values.title: Unify topic names

values.description:
See `subt-communication/README.md` for more details regarding this refactor of the existing virtual communication system for SUBT. It involves four new packages that replace and extend functionality that was previously in the `subt_gazebo` package. The `subt_gazebo` package continues to hold the Gazebo plugin that instantiates communication simulation:

* `subt_rf_interface`: Provides function signature \(and simple implementation\) for computing pathloss from transmitter/receiver locations.
* `subt_communication_model`: Provides function signature and implementation for evaluating packet communication success based on evaluation of a path loss function, modulation-based models of bit-error rate, and bitrate limitations of the configured radio.
* `subt_communication_broker`: Centralized node that handles communication requests via distributed client API. Is instantiated with function handles for \(1\) a pathloss function, \(2\) an `attempt_send` function, i.e., the communication model, and \(3\) an `update_pose` function that provides a mechanism to query the simulator for the pose of an agent by name.
* `subt_gazebo_los_model`: Pathloss function instantiation based on approximate visibility via a pre-computed lookup table. The so-called _visibility cost_ is used to affect the fading exponent for the generic range-based log-normal fading model. This means communication while in line-of-sight \(LOS\) will behave according to standard fading models and as LOS is lost, attenuation will happen much more rapidly.

**Note**: After this PR is merged, some validation/model-fitting should be performed along with testing in simulation to choose good parameters \(fading exponent, noise floor, link capacity, mapping visibility cost to fading exponent inflation\) that match somewhat realistic devices.

**Some other changes along the way include**:

* Add service to subt\_example for testing comms

    _Service will create pair of topics for externally analyzing communication peformance \(bitrate acheieved, latency, etc\)_


* Add subt\_comms\_test

    _Package to store communication system testing nodes and scripts._


* Fix subt\_example\_node comms LED blinking

    _LED blinking was limiting communication rate._


* Improved visibility visualization

    * _Improve speed of rendering using POINTS marker type_
    * _color-code points based on computed cost_
values.title: Comms refactor

summary.raw:
See `subt-communication/README.md` for more details regarding this refactor of the existing virtual communication system for SUBT. It involves four new packages that replace and extend functionality that was previously in the `subt_gazebo` package. The `subt_gazebo` package continues to hold the Gazebo plugin that instantiates communication simulation:

* `subt_rf_interface`: Provides function signature \(and simple implementation\) for computing pathloss from transmitter/receiver locations.
* `subt_communication_model`: Provides function signature and implementation for evaluating packet communication success based on evaluation of a path loss function, modulation-based models of bit-error rate, and bitrate limitations of the configured radio.
* `subt_communication_broker`: Centralized node that handles communication requests via distributed client API. Is instantiated with function handles for \(1\) a pathloss function, \(2\) an `attempt_send` function, i.e., the communication model, and \(3\) an `update_pose` function that provides a mechanism to query the simulator for the pose of an agent by name.
* `subt_gazebo_los_model`: Pathloss function instantiation based on approximate visibility via a pre-computed lookup table. The so-called _visibility cost_ is used to affect the fading exponent for the generic range-based log-normal fading model. This means communication while in line-of-sight \(LOS\) will behave according to standard fading models and as LOS is lost, attenuation will happen much more rapidly.

**Note**: After this PR is merged, some validation/model-fitting should be performed along with testing in simulation to choose good parameters \(fading exponent, noise floor, link capacity, mapping visibility cost to fading exponent inflation\) that match somewhat realistic devices.

**Some other changes along the way include**:

* Add service to subt\_example for testing comms

    _Service will create pair of topics for externally analyzing communication peformance \(bitrate acheieved, latency, etc\)_


* Add subt\_comms\_test

    _Package to store communication system testing nodes and scripts._


* Fix subt\_example\_node comms LED blinking

    _LED blinking was limiting communication rate._


* Improved visibility visualization

    * _Improve speed of rendering using POINTS marker type_
    * _color-code points based on computed cost_
summary.html:
See subt-communication/README.md for more details regarding this refactor of the existing virtual communication system for SUBT. It involves four new packages that replace and extend functionality that was previously in the subt_gazebo package. The subt_gazebo package continues to hold the Gazebo plugin that instantiates communication simulation:

  • subt_rf_interface: Provides function signature (and simple implementation) for computing pathloss from transmitter/receiver locations.
  • subt_communication_model: Provides function signature and implementation for evaluating packet communication success based on evaluation of a path loss function, modulation-based models of bit-error rate, and bitrate limitations of the configured radio.
  • subt_communication_broker: Centralized node that handles communication requests via distributed client API. Is instantiated with function handles for (1) a pathloss function, (2) an attempt_send function, i.e., the communication model, and (3) an update_pose function that provides a mechanism to query the simulator for the pose of an agent by name.
  • subt_gazebo_los_model: Pathloss function instantiation based on approximate visibility via a pre-computed lookup table. The so-called visibility cost is used to affect the fading exponent for the generic range-based log-normal fading model. This means communication while in line-of-sight (LOS) will behave according to standard fading models and as LOS is lost, attenuation will happen much more rapidly.

Note: After this PR is merged, some validation/model-fitting should be performed along with testing in simulation to choose good parameters (fading exponent, noise floor, link capacity, mapping visibility cost to fading exponent inflation) that match somewhat realistic devices.

Some other changes along the way include:

  • Add service to subt_example for testing comms

    Service will create pair of topics for externally analyzing communication peformance (bitrate acheieved, latency, etc)

  • Add subt_comms_test

    Package to store communication system testing nodes and scripts.

  • Fix subt_example_node comms LED blinking

    LED blinking was limiting communication rate.

  • Improved visibility visualization

    • Improve speed of rendering using POINTS marker type
    • color-code points based on computed cost

values.description: Collision box of staging area had a typo that was a mismatch of the visual box, resulting in an invisible empty gap between the edge of the collision box and the barrier. The fall-through in issue #37 seems to have happened at that gap.
values.title: Fix issue #37 staging area collision box

summary.raw: Collision box of staging area had a typo that was a mismatch of the visual box, resulting in an invisible empty gap between the edge of the collision box and the barrier. The fall-through in issue #37 seems to have happened at that gap.
summary.html: Collision box of staging area had a typo that was a mismatch of the visual box, resulting in an invisible empty gap between the edge of the collision box and the barrier. The fall-through in issue #37 seems to have happened at that gap.

values.description:
Convert tsv specification of tunnel system to dot topological graph.

Artifacts and blockers are ignored.

Constraints were required for 2x2 blocks and 3x3 blocks, otherwise all cells are densely connected. 2 x 2 case: Corner tunnel\_tile\_2 required hard-coded constraint dependent on mesh orientation. 3 x 3 case: Linear tiles \(tunnel\_tile\_\[5 | 6 | 7\], constrained\_tunnel\_tile\_\[tall | short\]\) required constraint dependent on mesh orientation - straight tiles are only allowed to be neighbors if they are in a straight line \(e.g. excludes parallel non-intersecting straight tiles\).

Heuristic for cost: straight to straight tile 1, straight to turn tile 3, turn tile to turn tile 3.
values.title: Topological map from tsv to dot

summary.raw:
Convert tsv specification of tunnel system to dot topological graph.

Artifacts and blockers are ignored.

Constraints were required for 2x2 blocks and 3x3 blocks, otherwise all cells are densely connected. 2 x 2 case: Corner tunnel\_tile\_2 required hard-coded constraint dependent on mesh orientation. 3 x 3 case: Linear tiles \(tunnel\_tile\_\[5 | 6 | 7\], constrained\_tunnel\_tile\_\[tall | short\]\) required constraint dependent on mesh orientation - straight tiles are only allowed to be neighbors if they are in a straight line \(e.g. excludes parallel non-intersecting straight tiles\).

Heuristic for cost: straight to straight tile 1, straight to turn tile 3, turn tile to turn tile 3.
summary.html:
Convert tsv specification of tunnel system to dot topological graph.

Artifacts and blockers are ignored.

Constraints were required for 2x2 blocks and 3x3 blocks, otherwise all cells are densely connected. 2 x 2 case: Corner tunnel_tile_2 required hard-coded constraint dependent on mesh orientation. 3 x 3 case: Linear tiles (tunnel_tile_[5 | 6 | 7], constrained_tunnel_tile_[tall | short]) required constraint dependent on mesh orientation - straight tiles are only allowed to be neighbors if they are in a straight line (e.g. excludes parallel non-intersecting straight tiles).

Heuristic for cost: straight to straight tile 1, straight to turn tile 3, turn tile to turn tile 3.

values.description:
This PR adds some boilerplate code copied from `subt_gazebo` to `subt_ign`. The idea is to keep ignition code in a separate package to prevent pollution.

The `subt2` target branch will be the release branch for version 2 of subt.
values.title: Added boilerplate code to subt_ign

summary.raw:
This PR adds some boilerplate code copied from `subt_gazebo` to `subt_ign`. The idea is to keep ignition code in a separate package to prevent pollution.

The `subt2` target branch will be the release branch for version 2 of subt.
summary.html:
This PR adds some boilerplate code copied from subt_gazebo to subt_ign. The idea is to keep ignition code in a separate package to prevent pollution.

The subt2 target branch will be the release branch for version 2 of subt.

values.description:
This migrates the game logic plugin to the ignition framework. Included in a new tunnel qual world that using ignition fuel, and an ignition launch file.

You will need the PRs in https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch

## Testing

1. `catkin_make install`
2. `ign launch -f competition.ign -v 4`
values.title: Added gamelogic plugin

values.description:
We want to add a  new robot configuration with two cameras for the robots X1, X2 and X4. These three robots already have configurations with a HD camera and a lidar. Replacing a lidar with an second HD camera should be possible. The robot X3 only carries one additional sensor. So adding a second camera to X3 might overload the copter and we did not add a two camera configuration to X3.

The two cameras are placed at the front of the robot. One a little bit to the right and the other one a little bit on the left. 

This configuration seems for us to be a good alternative. So we would like to have this configuration added to the robots.

Kind Regards

Wolfgang
values.title: new robot configuration with two cameras for X1, X2 and X4

So adding a second camera to X3 might overload the copter and we did not add a two camera configuration to X3.

The two cameras are placed at the front of the robot. One a little bit to the right and the other one a little bit on the left. 

This configuration seems for us to be a good alternative. So we would like to have this configuration added to the robots.

Kind Regards

Wolfgang
summary.html:
We want to add a new robot configuration with two cameras for the robots X1, X2 and X4. These three robots already have configurations with a HD camera and a lidar. Replacing a lidar with an second HD camera should be possible. The robot X3 only carries one additional sensor. So adding a second camera to X3 might overload the copter and we did not add a two camera configuration to X3.

The two cameras are placed at the front of the robot. One a little bit to the right and the other one a little bit on the left.

This configuration seems for us to be a good alternative. So we would like to have this configuration added to the robots.

Kind Regards

Wolfgang

values.description:
Initial check-in of the SubT scoring system for public visibility of the sample code and the drop-in ROS interfaces. The main information is in the [README.md](http://README.md) in commandpost\_relay, where I’ve explained the ROS interface to the ICD.

This should successfully build and and run on an Ubuntu 16.04 install with ROS Kinetic. I was a bit unsure if we’d shifted over into 18.04/Melodic quite yet.

This is not the full scoring server, though I think eventually we need to have \(a version of\) the scoring server in here simply so that the virtual testbed can be self-contained.
values.title: SubT Scoring System

summary.raw:
Initial check-in of the SubT scoring system for public visibility of the sample code and the drop-in ROS interfaces. The main information is in the [README.md](http://README.md) in commandpost\_relay, where I’ve explained the ROS interface to the ICD.

This should successfully build and and run on an Ubuntu 16.04 install with ROS Kinetic. I was a bit unsure if we’d shifted over into 18.04/Melodic quite yet.

This is not the full scoring server, though I think eventually we need to have \(a version of\) the scoring server in here simply so that the virtual testbed can be self-contained.
summary.html:
Initial check-in of the SubT scoring system for public visibility of the sample code and the drop-in ROS interfaces. The main information is in the README.md in commandpost_relay, where I’ve explained the ROS interface to the ICD.

This should successfully build and and run on an Ubuntu 16.04 install with ROS Kinetic. I was a bit unsure if we’d shifted over into 18.04/Melodic quite yet.

This is not the full scoring server, though I think eventually we need to have (a version of) the scoring server in here simply so that the virtual testbed can be self-contained.

values.reason: I believe the plan is to create a stand-alone scoring server that the virtual testbed will use instead of direct integration.

values.description:
Requires: https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/19

This is the initial port of the SubT communication to `subt2`.

* At this point, the `log_normal_range` mode should work.
*  I have included one plugin for testing the comms: `ControllerPlugin`.

For testing: Uncomment this block in `competition.ign`:

```
  <!-- Testing comms in X1 -->
  <!-- <plugin entity_name="X1"
          entity_type="model"
          name="subt::ControllerPlugin"
          filename="libControllerPluginIgn.so">
    <name>X1</name>
  </plugin> -->

  <!-- Testing comms in X2 -->
  <!-- <plugin entity_name="X2"
          entity_type="model"
          name="subt::ControllerPlugin"
          filename="libControllerPluginIgn.so">
    <name>X2</name>
  </plugin> -->
```

And run SubT:

```
ign launch -f competition.ign -v 4
```

```
ign launch -f team.ign -v 4
```

You should see in the terminal these messages confirming that the comms work:

```
[Msg] [X2] Message received from [X1]: [hello from X1]
[Msg] [X1] Message received from [X2]: [hello from X2]
[Msg] [X2] Message received from [X1]: [hello from X1]
[Msg] [X1] Message received from [X2]: [hello from X2]
```

You can even change the `max_range` parameter in the `CommsBrokerPlugin` from `20.0` to `0.001`, and in that case you shouldn’t get any messages.

ToDo features for future pull requests:

* Visibility range mode is not available. We need extra work to make it happen.
* Simple mode is not available. We need extra work to talk with the ROS parameter server.
* We can use some cleaning.
values.title: Ign comms

summary.raw:
Requires: https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/19

This is the initial port of the SubT communication to `subt2`.

* At this point, the `log_normal_range` mode should work.
*  I have included one plugin for testing the comms: `ControllerPlugin`.

For testing: Uncomment this block in `competition.ign`:

```
  <!-- Testing comms in X1 -->
  <!-- <plugin entity_name="X1"
          entity_type="model"
          name="subt::ControllerPlugin"
          filename="libControllerPluginIgn.so">
    <name>X1</name>
  </plugin> -->

  <!-- Testing comms in X2 -->
  <!-- <plugin entity_name="X2"
          entity_type="model"
          name="subt::ControllerPlugin"
          filename="libControllerPluginIgn.so">
    <name>X2</name>
  </plugin> -->
```

And run SubT:

```
ign launch -f competition.ign -v 4
```

```
ign launch -f team.ign -v 4
```

You should see in the terminal these messages confirming that the comms work:

```
[Msg] [X2] Message received from [X1]: [hello from X1]
[Msg] [X1] Message received from [X2]: [hello from X2]
[Msg] [X2] Message received from [X1]: [hello from X1]
[Msg] [X1] Message received from [X2]: [hello from X2]
```

You can even change the `max_range` parameter in the `CommsBrokerPlugin` from `20.0` to `0.001`, and in that case you shouldn’t get any messages.

ToDo features for future pull requests:

* Visibility range mode is not available. We need extra work to make it happen.
* Simple mode is not available. We need extra work to talk with the ROS parameter server.
* We can use some cleaning.
summary.html:
Requires: https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/19

This is the initial port of the SubT communication to subt2.

  • At this point, the log_normal_range mode should work.
  • I have included one plugin for testing the comms: ControllerPlugin.

For testing: Uncomment this block in competition.ign:

  <!-- Testing comms in X1 -->
  <!-- <plugin entity_name="X1"
          entity_type="model"
          name="subt::ControllerPlugin"
          filename="libControllerPluginIgn.so">
    <name>X1</name>
  </plugin> -->

  <!-- Testing comms in X2 -->
  <!-- <plugin entity_name="X2"
          entity_type="model"
          name="subt::ControllerPlugin"
          filename="libControllerPluginIgn.so">
    <name>X2</name>
  </plugin> -->

And run SubT:

ign launch -f competition.ign -v 4

ign launch -f team.ign -v 4

You should see in the terminal these messages confirming that the comms work:

[Msg] [X2] Message received from [X1]: [hello from X1]
[Msg] [X1] Message received from [X2]: [hello from X2]
[Msg] [X2] Message received from [X1]: [hello from X1]
[Msg] [X1] Message received from [X2]: [hello from X2]

You can even change the max_range parameter in the CommsBrokerPlugin from 20.0 to 0.001, and in that case you shouldn’t get any messages.

ToDo features for future pull requests:

  • Visibility range mode is not available. We need extra work to make it happen.
  • Simple mode is not available. We need extra work to talk with the ROS parameter server.
  • We can use some cleaning.

values.description:
* Expose received signal strength to the communication interface
* Update communication client with RSSI

    Fix neighbor state-reporting. Neighbors are only populated when receiving packets but the interface will also now report signal strength.


* Add simple publishing of RSSI in subt\_example\_node
* Update subt\_comms\_test to show RSSI

Fixes #51 and #64

values.description:
This is an attempt to integrate the Pose publisher and the multicopter systems to SubT. The Pose publisher currently publishes the absolute poses of models and the relative poses of links and sensors. This is fed into TF to allow ROS nodes access various transforms without the need for joint_state_publisher and robot_state_publisher.

The Multicoptor system is only added for the X3 for now. It is using the roll-pitch-yawrate-thrust controller from rotorS. Odometry for the controller is provided by the ukf_localization_node which fuses IMU data.

To test:
In one terminal, run
`ign launch subt/subt_ign/competition.ign`

In another terminal, run
`ign launch subt/subt_ign/team.ign`

This is currently setup to start a teleop node assuming the PS3 controller is used. You can use rviz with `subt_example/config/team.rviz` to visualize all the vehicles.

Requires:

* [ign-gazebo PR #322](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/322/blueprint-multicopter-motor-model/diff)
* ros-melodic-rotors-gazebo
values.title: Multicoptor integration

The Pose publisher currently publishes the absolute poses of models and the relative poses of links and sensors. This is fed into TF to allow ROS nodes access various transforms without the need for joint_state_publisher and robot_state_publisher.

The Multicoptor system is only added for the X3 for now. It is using the roll-pitch-yawrate-thrust controller from rotorS. Odometry for the controller is provided by the ukf_localization_node which fuses IMU data.

The Pose publisher currently publishes the absolute poses of models and the relative poses of links and sensors. This is fed into TF to allow ROS nodes access various transforms without the need for joint_state_publisher and robot_state_publisher.

The Multicoptor system is only added for the X3 for now. It is using the roll-pitch-yawrate-thrust controller from rotorS. Odometry for the controller is provided by the ukf_localization_node which fuses IMU data.

To test: In one terminal, run ign launch subt/subt_ign/competition.ign

In another terminal, run ign launch subt/subt_ign/team.ign

This is currently setup to start a teleop node assuming the PS3 controller is used. You can use rviz with subt_example/config/team.rviz to visualize all the vehicles.

Requires:

values.description:
Sample world with [Urban tiles](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/search;q=Urban). Since this is a proof of concept for the Urban pieces, the structure is just slightly modified from a previous Tunnel qualifier world.

`tile_tsv.py` from tunnel circuits is updated to generate urban world from `urban.tsv`. Urban tiles need to be scaled by 40. Tunnel tiles were scaled by 20.

```
python3 tile_tsv.py urban.tsv --world-name urban --scale_x 40 --scale_y 40 --x0 -10 --y0 240 > urban_standalone.sdf
```

Things that need to be fixed outside this PR:

* Straight tile’s color \(gray\) is darker than the other tiles \(green\).
* Subway station doesn’t have textures. `Plant_Albedo.png` is missing, indicated by this error:  
  `[Err] [Material.cc:143] Unable to find texture[Plant_Albedo.png] in path[/home/developer/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/Urban Station/1//meshes]`

The world can be inspected by:

```
cd subt/subt_ign/worlds
ign launch ../launch/urban.ign
ign launch ../launch/team.ign
ign topic -t "/model/x1/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 2.0}"
```

To see the full tunnel, set `<levels>false</levels>` in `urban.ign`.

‌
values.title: New urban world

values.description: There were a few issues with the topo_tsv.py script being in a separate file, since it was not using consistent names for the tile names. This is an attempt to add the functionality of the topo_tsv.py script into tile_tsv.py, so that the same model names are used for the tiles when generating the .world and .dot files. I've tested it a bit with the tunnel_qual.tsv, and currently the vertices section is largely unchanged, though I changed the vertex symbol for the base station to 'S' instead of a number. The edge outputs are very different, since they are sorted, so that's a bit tougher to evaluate.
values.title: Combine topo_tsv.py into tile_tsv.py

summary.raw: There were a few issues with the topo_tsv.py script being in a separate file, since it was not using consistent names for the tile names. This is an attempt to add the functionality of the topo_tsv.py script into tile_tsv.py, so that the same model names are used for the tiles when generating the .world and .dot files. I've tested it a bit with the tunnel_qual.tsv, and currently the vertices section is largely unchanged, though I changed the vertex symbol for the base station to 'S' instead of a number. The edge outputs are very different, since they are sorted, so that's a bit tougher to evaluate.

values.description:
Added run commands to download the robot models into the docker image. 

The important one is the \`subt\_sim\_entry\` but I noticed that other dockerfiles are also downloading the models so I added them there too. We should probably refactor the common parts of these Dockerfiles and create a base image from it. The reason I have not done this yet is because I’m not sure how that would affect the flow of pushing and pulling the images to and from AWS ECR.
values.title: Download the robot models in docker

summary.raw:
Added run commands to download the robot models into the docker image. 

The important one is the \`subt\_sim\_entry\` but I noticed that other dockerfiles are also downloading the models so I added them there too. We should probably refactor the common parts of these Dockerfiles and create a base image from it. The reason I have not done this yet is because I’m not sure how that would affect the flow of pushing and pulling the images to and from AWS ECR.
summary.html:
Added run commands to download the robot models into the docker image.

The important one is the `subt_sim_entry` but I noticed that other dockerfiles are also downloading the models so I added them there too. We should probably refactor the common parts of these Dockerfiles and create a base image from it. The reason I have not done this yet is because I’m not sure how that would affect the flow of pushing and pulling the images to and from AWS ECR.

values.description:
This pull request enables the `visibility_range` comms model type. If for some reason the `visibility_range` is selected but the required files are not present \( `.dot`and `.dat` files\), the plugin will automatically use `log_normal_range` as a fallback.

How do I test it?

* At this moment, we don't have the `.dot` and `.dat` files for the `virtual_stix` world, so we'll need to use `tunnel_qual_ign` for testing. Edit the file `subt_ign/launch/virtual_stix.ign` and replace `worldName = 'virtual_stix'` with `worldName = 'tunnel_qual_ign'`
* We need to exercise some communication between the robots. I created some testing controllers for this purpose. Edit the file `subt_ign/launch/team.ign` and uncomment the following two blocks at the end of the file:

```
<!-- Testing comms in X1 -->
<!-- <plugin entity_name="X1"
             entity_type="model"
             name="subt::ControllerPlugin"
             filename="libControllerPlugin.so">
  <name>X1</name>
</plugin> -->

<!-- Testing comms in X2 -->
<!-- <plugin entity_name="X2"
             entity_type="model"
             name="subt::ControllerPlugin"
             filename="libControllerPlugin.so">
  <name>X2</name>
</plugin> -->
```

* Recompile, and launch the world with:

```
ign launch virtual_stix.ign -v 4
```

* And in a separate terminal run:

```
ign launch team.ign -v 4
```

You should observe the following messages in the first terminal showing that the messages are actually received between X1 and X2:

```
[Msg] X1 controller loaded
[Msg] X2 controller loaded
[Msg] [X2] Msg sent
[Msg] [X1] Message received from [X2]: [hello from X2]
[Msg] [X1] Msg sent
[Msg] [X2] Message received from [X1]: [hello from X1]
[Msg] [X2] Msg sent
[Msg] [X1] Message received from [X2]: [hello from X2]
```
values.title: Visibility range

<!-- Testing comms in X1 -->

  • Recompile, and launch the world with:

You should observe the following messages in the first terminal showing that the messages are actually received between X1 and X2:

values.description:
This is some refactoring of the tile_tsv.py script that I did while merging @{557058:ceb5942c-6843-408c-8550-3ce4899d299b}'s work in pull request #106 into the tile_tsv.py script. I've pulled it here targeting the gazebo9 branch so I can add some artifact features on top of it.

The commit messages describe the changes pretty well:

* tile_tsv.py: support python3

* tile_tsv.py: use python3

* tile_tsv.py: add --world-file argument

* tile_tsv.py: update comms_model xml block

* tile_tsv.py: add print_world_top and print_world_bottom functions to clean up check_main

* tile_tsv.py: print script name with __file__, whitespace

* tile_tsv.py: move contents of print_tsv_model_includes to check_main function
values.title: tile_tsv.py refactoring (copied from pull request #144)

The commit messages describe the changes pretty well:

* tile_tsv.py: use python3

summary.html:
This is some refactoring of the tile_tsv.py script that I did while merging @Mabel Zhang's work in pull request #106 into the tile_tsv.py script. I've pulled it here targeting the gazebo9 branch so I can add some artifact features on top of it.

The commit messages describe the changes pretty well:

  • tile_tsv.py: support python3

  • tile_tsv.py: use python3

  • tile_tsv.py: add --world-file argument

  • tile_tsv.py: update comms_model xml block

  • tile_tsv.py: add print_world_top and print_world_bottom functions to clean up check_main

  • tile_tsv.py: print script name with file, whitespace

  • tile_tsv.py: move contents of print_tsv_model_includes to check_main function

values.description:
This PR updates virtual\_stix.ign to support spawning robots by passing arguments to the ign launch file.

The goal is that we want to stop the teams from spawning their own robots, and instead they will control existing robots in simulation. The teams will let us know the robots they would like to have in simulation before hand, e.g. through web UI, and we’ll pass them as arguments to the virtual\_stix.ign launch file

The launch args are `robotNameX` and `robotConfigX`, where X can range from 1 to 16. So they can spawn up to 16 robots for now. The `robotNameX` variable take any value but needs to be unique and the `robotConfigX` variable should be one of the configuration strings listed in our [api wiki page](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api). For example:

```
ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName3:=X3 robotConfig3:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName4:=X4 robotConfig4:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```

The args are optional, and spawning the robots through team.ign should still work.

Note that the teleop node is configured to send commands to `X1`, `X2`, `X3`, and `X4` robot names so it will not the robots are given different names

**Update:** changes also applied to virtual\_stix\_headless.ign. [6d463ae](#!/osrf/subt/commits/6d463aec695625f1f893de0e6a36125bd9f1ba8c)
values.title: Support spawning robots in virtual_stix.ign

summary.raw:
This PR updates virtual\_stix.ign to support spawning robots by passing arguments to the ign launch file.

The goal is that we want to stop the teams from spawning their own robots, and instead they will control existing robots in simulation. The teams will let us know the robots they would like to have in simulation before hand, e.g. through web UI, and we’ll pass them as arguments to the virtual\_stix.ign launch file

The launch args are `robotNameX` and `robotConfigX`, where X can range from 1 to 16. So they can spawn up to 16 robots for now. The `robotNameX` variable take any value but needs to be unique and the `robotConfigX` variable should be one of the configuration strings listed in our [api wiki page](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api). For example:

```
ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName3:=X3 robotConfig3:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName4:=X4 robotConfig4:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```

The args are optional, and spawning the robots through team.ign should still work.

Note that the teleop node is configured to send commands to `X1`, `X2`, `X3`, and `X4` robot names so it will not the robots are given different names

**Update:** changes also applied to virtual\_stix\_headless.ign. [6d463ae](#!/osrf/subt/commits/6d463aec695625f1f893de0e6a36125bd9f1ba8c)
summary.html:
This PR updates virtual_stix.ign to support spawning robots by passing arguments to the ign launch file.

The goal is that we want to stop the teams from spawning their own robots, and instead they will control existing robots in simulation. The teams will let us know the robots they would like to have in simulation before hand, e.g. through web UI, and we’ll pass them as arguments to the virtual_stix.ign launch file

The launch args are robotNameX and robotConfigX, where X can range from 1 to 16. So they can spawn up to 16 robots for now. The robotNameX variable take any value but needs to be unique and the robotConfigX variable should be one of the configuration strings listed in our api wiki page. For example:

ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName3:=X3 robotConfig3:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName4:=X4 robotConfig4:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

The args are optional, and spawning the robots through team.ign should still work.

Note that the teleop node is configured to send commands to X1, X2, X3, and X4 robot names so it will not the robots are given different names

Update: changes also applied to virtual_stix_headless.ign. 6d463ae

values.description:
Currently artifacts and blockers are defined in separate cells of the tsv spreadsheet, but this has some drawbacks, such as requiring manual adjustment of the artifact pose and limiting the density of tile placement. This pull request allows artifacts and blockers to be specified as submodels within a tile cell as the 4th field with a name of the submodel type and a pose.

Currently each cell has 3 fields:

| modelType | yawDegrees | z_level |
| --------|---------|-------|
| tunnel_tile_1 | 180 | -1 |
| tunnel_tile_blocker | 0 | -1 |
| Phone | 0 | -1 |

~~~
modelType,yawDegrees,z_level
tunnel_tile_1,180,-1
Phone,0,-1
~~~

This pull request adds a 4th field to each cell, which allows you to encode a list of submodel-pose pairs separated by `;`.

| modelType | yawDegrees | z_level | submodelPoseList |
| --------|---------|-------|-------|
| tunnel_tile_1 | 180 | -1 | tunnel_tile_blocker@11 0 0 0 0 0;Phone@0 0 0.004 -90 0 0 |

~~~
modelType,yawDegrees,z_level,submodelPoseList
tunnel_tile_1,180,-1,tunnel_tile_blocker@11 0 0 0 0 0;Phone@0 0 0.004 -90 0 0
~~~

If the `;` signifies a new row, this is like a small spreadsheet embedded in that 4th field (yo dawg).

| submodelType | Pose |
| --------|---------|
| tunnel_tile_blocker | 11 0 0 0 0 0 |
| Phone | 0 0 0.004 -90 0 0 |

For purposes of testing and review; I've tried to minimize changes to the tunnel_qual.world, but some were very difficult to avoid. Moving the `tunnel_tile_blocker`s to different cells has changed the numbering of the model names and their order within the world file, which is pretty messy. I did manage to maintain the formatting of pose strings the same by printing most pitch and roll angles as `0` instead of `0.0000`, which is a bit weird, but it helps with the following comparison.

To confirm that the world files have the same model types at the same locations, though with many name changes, I used the following commands to put the `<uri>` and `<pose>` tags on the same line, and then compare sorted versions of the file.

~~~
hg cat -r gazebo9 tunnel_qual.world \
 | tr '\n' ';' \
 | sed -e 's@</uri>;@</uri>@g' \
           -e 's@;@\n@g' \
 | sort > tunnel_qual_sorted_old.world
~~~

~~~
cat tunnel_qual.world \
 | tr '\n' ';' \
 | sed -e 's@</uri>;@</uri>@g' \
           -e 's@;@\n@g' \
 | sort > tunnel_qual_sorted_new.world
~~~

Then `tunnel_qual_sorted_old.world` and `tunnel_qual_sorted_new.world` should be identical.

This ruins `tunnel_qual.dot`, but I don't see an easy way to fix that.
values.title: tile_tsv.py: specify artifacts and blockers as 4th field in cell instead of empty cells

summary.raw:
Currently artifacts and blockers are defined in separate cells of the tsv spreadsheet, but this has some drawbacks, such as requiring manual adjustment of the artifact pose and limiting the density of tile placement. This pull request allows artifacts and blockers to be specified as submodels within a tile cell as the 4th field with a name of the submodel type and a pose.

Currently each cell has 3 fields:

| modelType | yawDegrees | z_level |
| --------|---------|-------|
| tunnel_tile_1 | 180 | -1 |
| tunnel_tile_blocker | 0 | -1 |
| Phone | 0 | -1 |

~~~
modelType,yawDegrees,z_level
tunnel_tile_1,180,-1
Phone,0,-1
~~~

This pull request adds a 4th field to each cell, which allows you to encode a list of submodel-pose pairs separated by `;`.

| modelType | yawDegrees | z_level | submodelPoseList |
| --------|---------|-------|-------|
| tunnel_tile_1 | 180 | -1 | tunnel_tile_blocker@11 0 0 0 0 0;Phone@0 0 0.004 -90 0 0 |

~~~
modelType,yawDegrees,z_level,submodelPoseList
tunnel_tile_1,180,-1,tunnel_tile_blocker@11 0 0 0 0 0;Phone@0 0 0.004 -90 0 0
~~~

If the `;` signifies a new row, this is like a small spreadsheet embedded in that 4th field (yo dawg).

| submodelType | Pose |
| --------|---------|
| tunnel_tile_blocker | 11 0 0 0 0 0 |
| Phone | 0 0 0.004 -90 0 0 |

For purposes of testing and review; I've tried to minimize changes to the tunnel_qual.world, but some were very difficult to avoid. Moving the `tunnel_tile_blocker`s to different cells has changed the numbering of the model names and their order within the world file, which is pretty messy. I did manage to maintain the formatting of pose strings the same by printing most pitch and roll angles as `0` instead of `0.0000`, which is a bit weird, but it helps with the following comparison.

To confirm that the world files have the same model types at the same locations, though with many name changes, I used the following commands to put the `<uri>` and `<pose>` tags on the same line, and then compare sorted versions of the file.

~~~
hg cat -r gazebo9 tunnel_qual.world \
 | tr '\n' ';' \
 | sed -e 's@</uri>;@</uri>@g' \
           -e 's@;@\n@g' \
 | sort > tunnel_qual_sorted_old.world
~~~

~~~
cat tunnel_qual.world \
 | tr '\n' ';' \
 | sed -e 's@</uri>;@</uri>@g' \
           -e 's@;@\n@g' \

~~~

Then `tunnel_qual_sorted_old.world` and `tunnel_qual_sorted_new.world` should be identical.

This ruins `tunnel_qual.dot`, but I don't see an easy way to fix that.
summary.html:
Currently artifacts and blockers are defined in separate cells of the tsv spreadsheet, but this has some drawbacks, such as requiring manual adjustment of the artifact pose and limiting the density of tile placement. This pull request allows artifacts and blockers to be specified as submodels within a tile cell as the 4th field with a name of the submodel type and a pose.

Currently each cell has 3 fields:

modelType yawDegrees z_level
tunnel_tile_1 180 -1
tunnel_tile_blocker 0 -1
Phone 0 -1 
modelType,yawDegrees,z_level
tunnel_tile_1,180,-1
Phone,0,-1

This pull request adds a 4th field to each cell, which allows you to encode a list of submodel-pose pairs separated by ;.

modelType yawDegrees z_level submodelPoseList
tunnel_tile_1 180 -1 tunnel_tile_blocker@11 0 0 0 0 0;Phone@0 0 0.004 -90 0 0 
modelType,yawDegrees,z_level,submodelPoseList
tunnel_tile_1,180,-1,tunnel_tile_blocker@11 0 0 0 0 0;Phone@0 0 0.004 -90 0 0

If the ; signifies a new row, this is like a small spreadsheet embedded in that 4th field (yo dawg).

submodelType Pose
tunnel_tile_blocker 11 0 0 0 0 0
Phone 0 0 0.004 -90 0 0

For purposes of testing and review; I've tried to minimize changes to the tunnel_qual.world, but some were very difficult to avoid. Moving the tunnel_tile_blockers to different cells has changed the numbering of the model names and their order within the world file, which is pretty messy. I did manage to maintain the formatting of pose strings the same by printing most pitch and roll angles as 0 instead of 0.0000, which is a bit weird, but it helps with the following comparison.

To confirm that the world files have the same model types at the same locations, though with many name changes, I used the following commands to put the <uri> and <pose> tags on the same line, and then compare sorted versions of the file.

hg cat -r gazebo9 tunnel_qual.world \
 | tr '\n' ';' \
 | sed -e 's@</uri>;@</uri>@g' \
           -e 's@;@\n@g' \
 | sort > tunnel_qual_sorted_old.world

cat tunnel_qual.world \
 | tr '\n' ';' \
 | sed -e 's@</uri>;@</uri>@g' \
           -e 's@;@\n@g' \
 | sort > tunnel_qual_sorted_new.world

Then tunnel_qual_sorted_old.world and tunnel_qual_sorted_new.world should be identical.

This ruins tunnel_qual.dot, but I don't see an easy way to fix that.
